awd_titl_txt: CCRI: Research Infrastructure: Planning-M: Multi-Modal Infrastructure for Enabling Social AI Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial intelligence (AI) for understanding social communication can play a key role in important application domains such as household robotics. However, current advancements in natural language processing and computer vision mainly focus on analyzing the surface structure of text and videos, lacking the ability to understand social communication deeply. 
 
To build large-scale AI systems that can better understand social interaction, this planning project aims at how to develop a process for collecting and annotating multi-modal and cross-cultural datasets of social communication in a responsible and sustainable way. The planning activities also include organizing workshops and panels around multi-modal social data collection to characterize the needs of this emerging social AI community.  
 
These planning activities will provide the foundation towards building the next generation of social AI models and ensuring that collection and use of the data complies with ethical and legal considerations. The resulting data infrastructure will facilitate future research on theory of mind, teamwork, and group decision-making.  This planning project will demonstrate the potential of interdisciplinary research between natural language processing, computer vision, social science, law, and ethics. 
 
This project will be hosted via this website: socialai-data.org, where data, code, and data use protocols will be actively updated and maintained during the project period.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
AI technologies that understand social communication are important for applications like conversational agents, home robots, and health interventions. To better communicate with users, social AI systems must go deeper, understanding why something was said beyond what was said as well as the combination of speech, gestures, and facial expressions in everyday settings. While large-scale datasets of transcribed speech and NLP corpora have contributed to advances in vision and NLP, social AI is hindered by the absence of multi-modal datasets containing social interactions situated in everyday contexts. This planning project focuses on social AI research by establishing an ethical, legal, scalable, and sustainable process for collecting and annotating multimodal datasets of social communication in cross-cultural contexts that cover the key aspects of social interaction. The project focuses on three main thrusts:  investigating the legal and ethical considerations that inform data collection; collecting multimodal data in real-life and naturalistic contexts; developing scalable and multi-cultural approaches to dataset curation that leverage web-scale platforms to support our goal of inclusive capture. 

 

Throughout this project, significant progress has been made across the three thrusts, providing a solid foundation for advancing social AI data infrastructure. Concretely, this project has undertaken several key activities. The first major activity has been around creating a thorough understanding of existing social AI dataset efforts, towards which, the team has contributed a comprehensive social AI taxonomy and a data library of 480 NLP datasets. This infrastructure provides resources and tools for researchers to understand existing dataset efforts around the social AI landscape and best practices around ethical considerations around data collection, emphasizing the need for multifaceted datasets that incorporate cultural diversity, long-tail social situations, and more interactive data formats.

 

The next major activity focuses on benchmarking 13 large language models (LLMs) on 25 representative social AI tasks. This comprehensive evaluation assessed whether current LLMs could handle complex social situations and social signals, particularly in zero-shot learning scenarios. The results showed that LLMs fell short compared to fine-tuned models in classification tasks around social contexts. This provides direct empirical support for the capability of LLMs on a wide range of social constructs, and points to where our efforts should be focused to advance Social AI.

 

Building on the aforementioned social AI data landscapes and empirical evidence, the project team developed a multimodal benchmark dataset that models social intelligence using persuasive behaviors during multiplayer social deduction games, in order to further multimodal data collection efforts.   This dataset was constructed from a mix of sources, including the Ego4D social dataset and YouTube videos, and includes both video data and transcribed dialogues annotated with persuasive strategy at the utterance level and voting outcomes, offering insight into the influence of video and contextual cues in persuasion behavior modeling.

 

Using diverse data from online communities, the project team has built Culturebank: an online community-driven knowledge base for developing culturally aware language technologies to advance such social understanding across cultures. A total of 12K cultural descriptors were sourced from TikTok and 11K from Reddit to form this knowledge base, which allows for diverse interpretations of cultural knowledge. Evaluations on CultureBank revealed areas where LLMs need to improve in cultural understanding, and fine-tuning LLMs on CultureBank data enhanced performance on cultural tasks.  The work provides concrete recommendations for building AI models that are more culturally aware. 

 

This one-year planning project has produced four research publications, and a set of open-source datasets and software tools. To foster community engagement, the project team has disseminated their findings through tutorials and research presentations across various research communities, covering representative works and best practices derived from the planning project. The project team has also begun building a research community focused on modeling multimodal social interactions, including organizing workshops for upcoming major conferences.

 

In conclusion, this planning project has laid significant groundwork for the future of social AI data infrastructure research. The comprehensive analysis of existing social AI datasets, the development of naturalistic multimodal benchmarks, and the creation of CultureBank contribute to the understanding of social constructs in AI research. The effort provides practical insight into the need for social intelligence in future AI systems in order to engage effectively with users across a variety of cultural contexts. The planning project also demonstrates interdisciplinary research between natural language processing, computer vision, psychology, and social sciences.  Overall, this planning project has established a strong foundation for the next phase of investigation, aiming at developing real-world and cross-cultural social AI data infrastructure and models.
